title: At what point did people stop using words like 'thou', 'ye' and so on? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mostly in the 1600’s. “Thou” didst barely make it to the American shores. The time around the English Revolution (1640–1660) was a period of great turmoil in all things cultural, religious, political, scientific… and it’s largely in this period that thee and thou didst fell into disuse, and other aspects of didst simplify themselves. Among the religious dissidents (including Separatists, Puritans, and Quakers) there was opposition to the distinction between informal vs. polite use, thou” vs. “ye” or “you” especially as it required common people to address their superiors (lords and kings) using the formal “you.” As also in French, where the polite “vous” is grammatically the second person plural, used as formal second person singular, “you” was grammatically the 2nd person plural. (Did you catch me saying ‘you was’?). The dissidents preferred to address everyone without respect to social class. The easy path was to raise everybody in status, calling everyone ‘you’, and that is the common usage today. The Quakers chose the opposite path, insisting on addressing any individual, regardless of status as ‘thou’ or ‘thee.’ In later times, though, the Quakers dropped the nominative/objective distinction between ‘thou’ and ‘thee’, and came to use ‘thee’ in nominative. Backing up a bit as to “ye” and “you” — in Middle English the 2nd person plural was generally “ye” in the nominative case and “eow” or “gu” in objective case. So, trending into the Early Modern English of Shakespeare or King James, those were “ye” as nominative, “you” as objective. But the same way as the Quakers dropped the nominative form “thou” and collapsed it with “thee” to be the all purpose 2nd person, in common usage the nominative “ye” was dropped and “you” took its place for all things. Now, about “ye” and “the”, that’s a different story, and a matter of orthography, not pronunciation. “Ye Olde Shoppe” would have been pronounced “the old shop” just as today, but ‘Y’ or something like it (left over from the old English letter ‘thorn’) was used by printers and scribes as a symbol for the ‘th’ sound. Others can go further into the weeds on that topic.

The pronouns for the second person singular, thou, and the second person plural, ye, are found in Old English and are still well-recorded into the 17th century (with some appearances after that). They reflect a period when, as still found in for instance the French tu and vous, different words were used when speaking to one or to several persons. At the same time you, which could be used for both singular and plural, can be seen in this sense from 1400 (there are several older, non-pronoun uses) and is used regularly from the 16th century onwards. Looking at the examples on offer in the OED, it is difficult to see a precise moment at which the all-purpose you replaces thou and ye. However it can be said with some certainty that it was pretty much in place by the 19th century and that if the latter pair do appear today, it will only be in an archaic, literary or poetical context.  For the subsidiary and much wider ranging question, I would recommend a couple of titles: AC Baugh and T Cable A History of the English Language which is an accessible and regularly revised (most recent edition 2002) take on the subject, and Henry Hitchings The Language Wars (2010) which deals with the whole concept of 'proper' English and its development since the Middle Ages. There are doubtless many, many more.

I'm from Yorkshire. We still use thee and thou, sithee. So do some other Northern dialects. ‘You' is the polite form of the second person pronoun. ‘Thee' is the familiar. This may confuse people mostly familiar with the words from Shakespeare or in a religious context - the hymn How great thou art, the line ‘Hallowed be thy name’ from the KJV Lord's Prayer. Shakespeare may seem highbrow today, but he wrote in the language of the people. And if you're not familiar with God, what sort of a Christian are you? He seems familiar with you. Yorkshire folk use ‘you’ for strangers and acquaintances, or when we're speaking ‘nicely'. For friends and neighbours people will often still use ‘thee’. Tha thees them as thees thee, as we say: you use ‘thee’ with the people who use ‘thee’ with you. It sounds much better in Yorkshire dialect.

Some people still do. I grew up ( in the Fifties) speaking “the plain language” at home. Quakers used thee and thy when talking among themselves. It still slips out in daily life from time to time. To me when I say thee I am speaking to the person’s higher self, soul. I find it slips out when I am mindfully thankful to someone. Although I can still hear my Grandmother calling to me, “Susie,get thee down here right now!” I knew I was in trouble. Thee and thy were always used in our home when writing letters.

As an aside, I love to teach church groups the difference in ye/thee & you/thou, because it's a fascinating and intentional variable in the scriptures.  When the Bible says "choose you this day whom ye will serve but as for me and my house we will serve the Lord," they mean for the reader to catch the intentional contrast there.  Ditto with "shall vs. will."  When the Bible says "if he will repent he shall be blessed," it is again supposed to jump out at you.  Ping me with questions.
"Thou" is still used in some British dialects, and by "plain speech" Quakers.
